section.title: Saving HamQSLer Card Files
section.para: Once a card has been created, it may be saved to be loaded and used at a future time. To do this, select the Cards->File Save or Cards->File Save As... menu items. File Save is only available if the card has previously been saved because the program must know the directory in which you want to save the card.
When you select the Card Save As... menu item, the File Save As dialog, shown below, is displayed.

The dialog opens with the default directory set to your hamqsler folder. Navigate to the folder where you want to save the card file, enter the name you want to save the file as, and then click on the Save button. The card file will be saved and the dialog will close.

section.title: Loading HamQSLer Card Files
section.para: Once a card has been saved, it can be loaded at a later time by selecting the Cards->Open Card... menu item. This displays the File Open dialog with the default directory set to your hamqsler folder. See the image below:
Navigate to the directory containing the card file you want to open, and either click on the file and then the Open button, or double-click on the file.

tip.para: Keep all of your card related files (card files, images, logos, etc.) in the hamqsler directory or create subdirectories for each file type. That way, all of the files needed for your cards are located in one place so they are easy to back up and to move to another location.

In the past, as Microsoft released new versions of Windows, they sometimes changed the location of the My Directories folder. This occurred, for example, when Windows Vista was released, and people who upgraded from Windows XP had problems with hard-coded paths.

If you want to reload the saved card or cards every time you restart the program, check the "Reload Card Files on Startup" checkbox in the User Preferences. See the User Preferences chapter for more information.

section.title: Moving and Converting QslDesignAndPrint Files
section.para: QslDesignAndPrint card files are normally stored in the QslDnP subdirectory of your My Documents directory. You may also have stored other related files such as images, logos, and possibly ADIF files in QslDnP.

HamQSLer uses the hamqsler subdirectory in My Documents. To ease the transition from QslDesignAndPrint to HamQSLer, a move and convert tool has been included in HamQSLer. This tool may be executed by selecting the "Import QslDesignAndPrint Files" menu item in the Tools dropdown menu.This tool performs two tasks:

listitem.para: All files except log files, card files, and the user preferences file are copied from QslDnP to hamqsler. The contents of all subdirectories except Logs and Samples are also copied. The user preferences file is not copied because there are many differences between QslDesignAndPrint user preferences and HamQSLer user preferences.
Card files are converted from QslDesignAndPrint format to HamQSLer format and copied to the directory and its subdirectores. Again the contents of the Logs and Samples subdirectories are ignored.

section.para: If one or more errors occur when copying files from QslDnP to hamqsler, the following message box will be displayed, and as noted, the file or files that could not be copied are listed in the log file along with the reason why.

If an image in a QslDesignAndPrint card file references an image file in QslDnP, then the location of the image file is changed from QslDnP to hamqsler. If any image file cannot be located, then the message box shown below is displayed, and you are given the choice between trying to locate the file yourself or deleting the image.

figure.title: Image File Not Found Message Box

section.para: When all files have been moved and all card files have been converted, the text "QslDnP files have been copied and card files converted." is displayed in the status bar at the bottom of HamQSLer's main window.

caution.para: HamQSLer uses a different graphical user interface than QslDesignAndPrint to draw cards. In some cases, font face names are different; if your card file references one of these font face names, then the card will not display text in your selected font. While the card files are being converted, no attempt is made to ensure that the font face name is valid. You may of course change the font face at any time while the card is in design mode.

QslDesignAndPrint supports three font weights: normal, bold, and black. HamQSLer only supports normal and bold. For most font faces used in QslDesignAndPrint, black is simply displayed as bold. The one obvious font face for which there is a black font weight is Arial.

An Arial Black font is available on the Internet, but it does not look like Arial with a font weight of black. An alternative to Arial Black is Helvetica Black. You may purchase Helvetica fonts, but they are not available free of charge, and will only be available on your computer if another application has loaded them.
An alternative font face with thicker characters is Verdana, although character shapes are different from Arial.
